content: The Act is titled the "Securities Litigation Attorney Accountability and Transparency Act." It states that the losing plaintiff's attorney must pay. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 has been amended to include a new paragraph regarding the assessment of fees and expenses in private actions. If a final judgment is entered against a plaintiff based on certain motions, the court must determine if the plaintiff's position was not justified, if imposing fees on the plaintiff's attorney is just, and the cost of such fees and expenses. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 has been amended to include a provision where if a final judgment is entered against a plaintiff, the court must assess if the plaintiff's position was unjustified, the burden of fees on the plaintiff's attorney, and the substantial burden of fees and expenses on the defendant. If the court determines these factors, the defendant will be awarded reasonable fees and expenses, with the burden of proof on the defendant. The Securities Act of 1933 has been amended to include a provision where the burden of fees and expenses may be imposed on the plaintiff's attorney if the court determines the plaintiff's position was not substantially justified. The Securities Act of 1933 has been amended to allow courts to impose reasonable fees and expenses on a plaintiff's attorney if the court determines that the plaintiff's position was not substantially justified. The Securities Act of 1933 allows courts to impose fees and expenses on a plaintiff's attorney if their position is not substantially justified, with the burden of persuasion on the defendant. SEC. 3. Requires disclosure of payments, fee arrangements, contributions, and conflicts of interest between plaintiff and attorneys. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include disclosures regarding payments in private actions. Plaintiffs and their attorneys must provide sworn certifications identifying any payments beyond the plaintiff's share. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires disclosures of payments in private actions. Plaintiffs and their attorneys must provide sworn certifications of any payments beyond the plaintiff's share. The attorney for the plaintiff must provide sworn certifications detailing any legal representation provided to the plaintiff in private actions. The court may allow these certifications to be made under seal and will determine if the fee arrangement influenced the selection of counsel. If so, the attorney will be disqualified from representing the plaintiff. In private actions, plaintiffs and their attorneys must disclose any contributions made to elected officials within five years prior to filing the complaint. Additionally, they must provide sworn certifications of any other conflicts of interest. In private actions, plaintiffs and their attorneys must disclose any conflicts of interest other than those specified in paragraphs (10) through (12) and provide sworn certifications. The court will determine if the conflict is sufficient to disqualify the attorney from representing the plaintiff. The court will determine if the conflict is enough to disqualify the attorney from representing the plaintiff. SEC. 4. SELECTION OF LEAD COUNSEL. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to require courts to use a competitive bidding process in selecting lead counsel for plaintiffs, unless deemed infeasible. SEC. 5. STUDY OF AVERAGE HOURLY FEES IN SECURITIES CLASS ACTIONS. The Comptroller General of the United States will study fee awards to lead counsel in securities class actions over the past five years to determine their average hourly rate. A report on the findings must be submitted to the Senate and House committees within a year of this Act's enactment, with updates every three years. The Securities Act of 1933 or the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 can be the basis for a plaintiff class action under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
